The utilization of non-precious nickel-based catalyst in increasing ammonia dissociation for COx-free hydrogen production was investigated. Typically, Co, La and basic metal oxides (Na, K, Ba) promoters were synthesized with nickel over acidic gamma alumina support. The main objective of the study was to modify the acid-base surface of catalyst structure thereby increasing ammonia dissociation activity. The catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition was strongly influenced by the addition of Na and K oxide promoters over 15 %Ni/Al2O3 resulting in moderate-stronger basic sites suitable for ammonia conversion. The addition of Na and K oxides showed a clear trend in tuning the trimetallic catalyst and significantly reducing the amount of strongly adsorbed hydrogen on the catalyst surface. This results in higher ammonia conversion which increased as a function of temperature to 32.4 %, 67.5 % and 95.3 % at 430 ᵒC, 485 ᵒC, and 533 ᵒC, respectively. Ammonia conversion using promoters was stable with no degradation of performance and the conversion increased with the decrease in WHSV. The catalytic reactivity over trimetallic catalysts was systematically influenced by their basic-acidic property that promoted ammonia dehydrogenation on the surface of nickel oxide-based catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ammonia cracking Hydrogen carrier Nickel-based catalyst Promoters Acid-base surface catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction The increase in global green energy and hydrogen fuel trend towards net zero emission for transportation fuel are expected to surge hydrogen production [1,2]. The decarbonization of energy processes will boost the use of ammonia as a hydrogen carrier due to its higher H2 content [3,4] compared to other hydrocarbon streams including methanol [4,5] and methylcyclohexane [4]. However, the catalytic decomposition of ammonia is still challenging in term of catalyst development [6]. Ammonia is a basic gas and its decomposition reaction is endothermic [3]. Ammonia dissociation requires several steps comprising adsorption over active catalyst/support, enough binding energy for nitrogen-hydrogen (NH) bond activation for hydrogen abstraction via dehydrogenation followed by desorption of N2 and H2 [7]. Several catalysts based on Ru [4,5], Ni [8,9], Fe [10–12] and Co [3] that were investigated for ammonia cracking showed the most active catalysts. However, these catalysts required selected supports and promoters [13] to upsurge the catalytic activity for higher ammonia conversion and lowering the cracking temperature [7]. Nickel-based catalyst is a low-cost and promising catalyst material which achieved high conversion of ammonia to hydrogen at >650 ᵒC [14]. Several studies have investigated the use of rare earth metal oxide of Ce, La, Sm, Gd or Y as promoters to nickel oxide over various supports of ZSM-5, Al2O3, SBA-15, USY and CNT to improve ammonia conversion. However, this improvement was attributed to reducing cracking temperature from ∼650–700 ᵒC to 550–600 ᵒC. Alternatively, several studies investigated the effect of metal oxide promoters mixed with nickel to increase ammonia conversion at lower temperatures for NH bond dissociation. Basic metal oxides from alkaline-earth metals Mg [9], Sr [9], Ca [9] and Ba [8,9] incorporated with NiO over acidic Al2O3 support, were intended to increase the basicity to promote catalyst activity towards higher ammonia conversion. The addition of Ba oxide was a promising promoter to NiO over alumina achieving the highest ammonia conversion between ∼80–95% [8,9] at 550 ᵒC. Similarly, basic metal oxides of Mg, Sr, Ba and Ca incorporated with NiO over strong acidic USY zeolite support were used to increase the adsorption of ammonia gas [15]. However, at 600 ᵒC the decomposition of ammonia over Ba-Ni/USY resulted in two-fold lower conversion compared with Ba-Ni over moderate acidic surface alumina oxide support [14]. In this study, five metal oxides promoters of Na, K, Ba, Co and La were selected to improve nickel oxide activity for ammonia decomposition. These promoters are expected to improve the bifunctionality of catalyst activity by enhancing the catalyst basicity which is intended to increase ammonia adsorption, dissociation and product desorption from catalyst surface at lower temperature and higher conversion. Two alkali metal promoters of Na and K, have not been investigated as promoters for Ni oxide; however, they were used with the noble metal Ru oxide supported with CNT or Pr6O11 rare earth. The addition of promoters resulted in improving the catalyst activity for ammonia conversion at lower temperatures. Similarly, the addition of Ba was used with the active metal oxides Co-Ce [3] and Ni [9] mainly to lower ammonia conversion temperature from 600 ᵒC to ∼500 ᵒC [16] and 550 ᵒC [9], respectively. Although, using Co as promoter for Ni oxide catalyst has not been studied, Co combined with Ce oxide (80%Co-20%Ce) promoted with Ba oxide catalyst showed promising conversion of ammonia (53%) at 485 ᵒC [3]. Similarly, La oxide promoter was utilized as reference to promote Ni oxide and the conversion of ammonia reached 75% at 500 ᵒC [16] and 92% at 550 ᵒC [17]. Herein, the effect of basic metal promoters including Na, K and Ba with Ni oxide was investigated. Moreover, gamma alumina was utilized as moderate acidic support for ammonia conversion. In addition, two metallic oxides of Co and La were also investigated to increase surface basicity by inducing transition and rare earth metals incorporated with Ni oxide for better dehydrogenation of ammonia at lower temperature. The modification of Ni oxide structure with promoter is expected to increase bifunctionality of the catalyst by amplifying promoter-metal-support interaction. This will accelerate NH bond dissociation over improved catalyst activity and elevate catalytic performance for higher ammonia conversion. Experimental Materials Gamma alumina, nickel(II) nitrate hexahydrate, sodium hydroxide, potassium hydroxide, barium acetate, cobalt nitrate hexahydrate, lanthanum chloride were purchased from Alfa Aesar and Fisher Scientific. Preparation of trimetallic nickel-based catalyst Low loading of 2% basic metal oxide (Na, K and Ba) was added to 15% Ni oxide, whereas 5% transition and rare metals of Co and La were added to 15% Ni oxide. All catalysts were supported on gamma alumina. The formulated trimetallic catalyst 15%Ni2%Na/Al2O3 and bimetallic catalyst 15%Ni/Al2O3 were prepared by wet impregnation method [18]. The nickel solution was formed by dissolving nickel nitrate salt (7.5 g) into reverse osmosis (RO) water (100 ml) and stirred for 5 min. Moreover, the trimetallic catalysts were prepared by adding a second metal salt or hydroxide (NaOH 0.35 g) to first solution and mixed again for 3 min. The gamma alumina support (10 g) was added to Ni and Na solution followed by mixing for 120 min at room temperature. The catalyst precursor was placed into a vacuum oven for 24 h at 100 °C before calcination under static air at 550 °C. Characterization The calcined trimetallic catalyst samples were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) from Rigaku Miniflex II X-ray diffractometer. The instrument was operated with a Cu Kα radiation at λ = 1.5406 Å at 30 KV and 15 mA, a scan angle between 10 and 70 ° was applied at speed of 1°min−1 and 0.02° step size. The surface topology and metal mapping of trimetallic oxide catalysts were investigated using scanning electron microscope (SEM) of FEI Quanta 400 instrument with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The textural properties of the catalysts were analyzed by N2 adsorption to determine surface area, pores size and pore volume using Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. The catalyst surface acidity was measured by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) using Micromeritics Autochem 2910. The surface basic sites of the trimetallic catalysts were analyzed using CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) via Micromeritics Autochem 2910 instrument. Hydrogen reduction of the catalysts was conducted by hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) method using Micromeritics Autochem 2910 instrument. The desorption of hydrogen and nitrogen behavior over catalysts were conducted, first a catalyst reduction at 500 ᵒC for 3 h under H2 flow of 50 ml/min. The H2-TPD was conducted separately and desorption temperature started at 100 to 900 ᵒC at heating rate of 10 ᵒC/min using Micromeritics Autochem 2910 instrument. Ammonia decomposition test Ammonia decomposition test was carried out using Micromeritics Autochem 2910 instrument connected with MKS quadrupole mass spectrometry (QMS) via Cirrus 2 instrument for real-time gas analysis. A catalyst weight of 0.2 g was loaded into quartz tube and hydrogen reduction was conducted at 500 °C under 10% hydrogen in 90% argon gas at a flow of 50 ml/min for 90 min. Then, the catalyst was cooled to 300 °C under helium flow rate (50 ml/min). The 10% ammonia in 90% helium at flow of 30 ml/min was introduced to test ammonia decomposition catalyst performance at temperatures between 330 and 630 °C. Ammonia conversion was calculated as described in eq. (1) [8]. (1) Conversion of ammonia ( mol % ) = F e e d i n ( m o l ) − F e e d o u t ( m o l ) F e e d i n ( m o l ) x 100 Results and discussion Catalyst XRD, EDS metal mapping and textural properties The gamma alumina and 15% nickel oxide supported were used as reference materials for XRD characterization to compare with the prepared five trimetallic catalysts. The gamma alumina exhibited broader XRD peaks detected at 21°, 37°, 40.3°, 47°, and 67.4° [19] as shown in Fig. 1 . Bimetallic 15% nickel oxide supported on gamma alumina showed XRD peaks at 44° and 63.8° [20]. Metals addition of Na, Ba, K and La oxides with 15%NiO and supported on gamma Al2O3 did not show any diffraction peaks due to the small concentration used with nickel-based catalyst. X-ray diffraction of 5% cobalt oxide with Ni oxide showed diffraction peaks at 31.9°, 45.2°, 55.8°, 60.2°, and 65.5° which are attributed to strong diffraction of Co oxide [21]. SEM-EDS analysis was conducted for nickel-based catalysts and the metal mapping (Figs. 2 A-F) confirmed the combination of synthesized five trimetallic catalysts. The addition of third metal to nickel oxide was well dispersed and distributed over gamma alumina. The textural properties of the five nickel-based trimetallic catalysts were compared with gamma alumina support and 15%Ni/Al2O3. It was observed that the surface area of alumina (216.5 m2/g) was decreased to 189.6 m2/g due to the addition of 15% nickel oxide as shown in Table 1 . Similarly, the addition of third metal oxide during the preparation of trimetallic catalysts resulted in a further slight reduction in surface area to the range of 166.9–184.8 m2/g. Figs. 3 A and 3B show pore size distribution with slightly reduced pore volume because of the addition of third metal in trimetallic catalysts [9,19]. Reducibility of the nickel-based catalysts Temperature programmed reduction gives information on metal-support interactions and elucidates the role of promoters in the reduction of active species. The reduction profile of five trimetallic nickel-based oxide catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 and the total amount of H2 consumed in Table 1. The reduction of 15%Ni/Al2O3 showed a wider reduction peak starting from 420 °C to 870 °C. The broad peak is assigned to the reduction of oxidized Ni species strongly interacting with the support and possibly from the reduction of NiAl2O4. The addition of third metal led to a wider reduction temperature profile and increased of total amount of H2 consumed compared to the bimetallic 15%Ni/Al2O3 [22–24]. The addition of Co resulted in reduction temperature starting at 350 ᵒC which is lower than 15%Ni/Al2O3. This indicates that CoO dissolved with NiO during co-participating impregnation of catalyst over alumina support. On the other hand, two small reduction peaks at Tmax 300 °C and 400 °C were observed for La oxide and a wider reduction peak between 450 and 850 °C for La oxide similar to observation noted earlier [25]. The addition of La enhanced the reduction of oxidized Ni species indicating an increase in the amount of oxidized Ni species weakly interacting with the Al2O3 support [17]. Moreover, the addition of Na oxide resulted in a reduction peak at lower temperature of 350 °C [26]. Therefore, the reduction temperature between 350 and 500 °C is essential to activate ammonia dissociation over the catalyst. The addition of Co, La, K, Ba and Na improved the reduction magnitude at temperatures between 400 and 500 °C and increased by two-fold than the original bimetallic catalyst (15%Ni/Al2O3), which is essential for ammonia cracking catalyst activity. Catalyst surface acidity and basicity The surface acidity of gamma Al2O3 and bimetallic 15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was investigated using NH3-TPD method. The impregnation of Ni oxide over acidic support reduced the total surface acidity of gamma alumina. Table 1 showed that the total surface acidity of 15%Ni/Al2O3 was higher (0.2–0.7-fold) than the observed acidity after the addition of transition (Co and La) and basic metal oxide (Na, K and Ba). Accordingly, Figs. 5 A and 5B showed that the addition of metal as a third metal oxide resulted in reduction in acidity region above around 300 ᵒC. In addition, the high temperature acidity strength of five trimetallic oxide catalysts were altered and a decrease in surface acidity strength region of about 0.5–1.6-fold compared to bimetallic 15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst as shown in Table 1. Hence, it can be inferred that, the acidic sites, especially the strong acidic sites on Al2O3 and 15%Ni/Al2O3 were covered by the addition of promoters [27,28]. The basicity of the catalysts and the addition of a third metal to 15%Ni/Al2O3 are essential for ammonia adsorption/desorption to prompt NH bond dissociation followed by hydrogen and nitrogen desorption from catalyst surface. The CO2-TPD evaluation was conducted to determine the surface basic sites distributed over the trimetallic nickel-based catalysts. The CO2 desorption strength profiles are illustrated in Table 2 . The three CO2 desorption intensities of basic sites temperature regions were distributed over catalysts [29–31]. The low temperature basic strength sites of CO2 desorption between temperature 60–420 ᵒC are likely related to the bicarbonates species [30–34]. The middle basic strength sites between 420 and 610 ᵒC are related to bidentate carbonates and linked with less oxide coordination state of metallic oxide catalyst represented to more basic surface oxygen anions [30,31,34-38]. The highest temperature region known by strong basic sites at desorption temperature above 610 ᵒC is indicative of oxycarbonate intermediate over catalyst [30,31]. The alumina has surface acidic–basic properties [19] and Fig. 5C shows that alumina contained surface basic sites distributed between low, middle and high temperature strength of CO2 desorption. The addition of Ni oxide to alumina resulted in little improvement in surface basicity sites at low and middle temperature strength (Table 2). Figs. 5C and 5D showed that the addition of third metal increased the basicity sites of moderate and high temperature strength which are an essential for ammonia conversion reaction zone over modified catalysts. The addition of K, Na and Co led to have more basicity especially in the moderate and high temperature strength zone. The addition of Ba and La also enhanced both the moderate and strong basicity sites. As mentioned earlier, the addition of third metal oxide attributed to a change in the number of acidic–basic properties between 350 and 500 ᵒC for the moderate basic sites and > 600 for the strong basic sites, which are considerably an essential condition for catalyst surface adsorption/desorption [39] and hence for higher catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition. This is achieved by suppressing the H2 inhibition effect from the catalyst surface. H2 surface desorption Throughout the sequential dissociation steps of ammonia to hydrogen and nitrogen over catalyst, it is essential to comprehend the hydrogen desorption behavior using H2-TPD over modified catalysts. The hydrogen desorption profiles for the addition of Co, La and basic metal oxides (Na, K, Ba) promoters to 15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst showed bimodal peaks consisting of low and high temperature strength of hydrogen desorption as depicted in Figs. 6 A and 6B. The three promoters showed shifting of desorption profile to a weaker temperature strength compared with original 15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. The hydrogen desorption over K and Na were shifted to low H2 weak desorption temperature compared to the addition of Ba to 15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Similarly, the addition of Co and La to 15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst reduced the weak desorption temperature strength and shifted to lower temperature compared to 15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. Thus, the promoter is likely to weakening H2 desorption temperature strength to assist the progress of H2 dissociation/ desorption to promote more ammonia dissociation. Addition of Co and La oxide to nickel-based catalyst Ammonia molecule is a basic gas that prefers acidic catalyst surface for adsorption while the cracking of ammonia to hydrogen is an endothermic reaction [38]. Accordingly, ammonia conversion over 15%Ni/Al2O3 and all trimetallic oxide catalysts was initiated at 338 ᵒC and ammonia decomposition increased with increasing reaction temperature [8]. Ammonia conversion over bimetallic 15%Ni/Al2O3 without addition of promoter reached 70% at 550 ᵒC (Fig. 7 ) and similar observation was reported by Okura et al. [17]. The addition of Co and La over Ni/Al2O3 showed an improvement in the acidic–basic sites of trimetallic oxide catalyst, with improved basic properties of trimetallic catalysis but were found to be lower than the addition of basic alkali metal oxide of Na and K. Co and La addition resulted in increase of moderate basicity strength between 350 and 500 ᵒC, improved strong basic sites and reduction of acidic sites slightly at wider temperature zone between 300 and 500 ᵒC (Fig. 5D). Furthermore, the addition of Co showed wider H2 reduction phase between 350 and 500 °C than the addition of La to bimetallic 15%Ni/Al2O3. This indicates that the catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition over La and Co addition would upsurge over trimetallic catalyst. Consequently, the catalytic behavior of La addition was examined and the ammonia conversion increased as a function of temperature to 17.6%, 39.4% and 73.9% at 430 ᵒC, 485 ᵒC, to 533 ᵒC, respectively. These ammonia conversion results were higher than using bimetallic 15% Ni/Al2O3, and similar observation was reported by Zhang et al. [16]. Co addition was expected to promote cracking catalytic activity and ammonia conversion, hence higher conversions reaching 30%, 53.1% and 84.4% at 430 ᵒC, 485 ᵒC, to 533 ᵒC, respectively, were achieved. The trimetallic oxide using Co and La achieved an increase of catalyst activity and promote higher ammonia conversion than the bimetallic oxide of 15%Ni/Al2O3. Addition of basic metal oxide of Na, K and Ba to nickel-based catalyst The addition of Na, K and Ba over 15%Ni/Al2O3 showed enhancement of acidic–basic surface sites of catalyst. Moreover, the addition of Na and K oxides attributed stronger basic sites between 250ᵒC to 525 ᵒC (Fig. 5C) located at the ammonia conversion temperature zone, and associated with a reduction of acidic strength sites between 250 and 500 ᵒC (Fig. 5A). On the other hand, the addition of Ba oxide showed similar basicity strength with Co oxide, but lower intensity than that of Na and K oxide addition (Fig. 5C, Table 2). The acidic strength sites of Ba oxide addition were stronger than Na and K oxides addition to 15%Ni/Al2O3. Therefore, the catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition was strongly influenced by the addition of Na and K oxides and both achieved the highest ammonia conversion as a function of temperature reaching 32.4%, 67.5% and 95.3% at 430 ᵒC, 485 ᵒC, and 533 ᵒC (Fig. 7), respectively. The addition of Ba oxide achieved lower ammonia conversion compared to Na and K oxides addition. The Ba oxide addition resulted in ammonia conversion of 17.8%, 42.9% and 80% at reaction temperatures of 430 ᵒC, 485 ᵒC, and 533 ᵒC (Fig. 8 ), respectively. This result is similar to an observation reported by Im et al. [9]. The addition of Ba achieved a similar ammonia conversion with Co oxide addition to 15%Ni/Al2O3. The catalytic reactivity over trimetallic catalysts was systematically influenced by their basic-acidic properties which is reflected on the dehydrogenation of ammonia. The addition of Na and K oxides resulted in lower H2 desorption (Fig. 6B), attributed to a clear trend for higher activity trimetallic catalyst and significantly improved the NH bond activation for higher ammonia conversion. The effect of gas hourly space velocity and conversion stability The addition of Na and K oxides to 15%Ni/Al2O3 resulted in the highest conversion of ammonia. Fig. 9 shows that ammonia conversion was affected by WHSV. Ammonia decomposition activity at 485 ᵒC showed an increase in ammonia conversion to 79.2% at WHSV 300 ml.g − 1h−1. Ammonia decomposition decreased with the increase in space velocity which is in agreement with previous observation [38]. Fig. 10 shows the stability test of ammonia conversion that was investigated by the addition of K oxide to bimetallic catalyst (15%Ni/Al2O3) forming the trimetallic catalyst 15%Ni2%K/Al2O3 at 485 ᵒC and WHSV 450 ml.g − 1h−1. During the time-on-steam of 240 min, the conversion of ammonia was notably stable within 69% to 74% and no degradation in performance. This result elucidated that the addition of K to15%Ni/Al2O3 catalyst resulted in highly stable catalyst for ammonia conversion. Performance comparison with different catalysts The performance of different catalysts reported in the literature has been compared with the promoted catalysts reported in this study. The results are presented in Table 3 depicting the catalysts composition, synthesis method, reaction temperature and NH3 conversion obtained. All the catalysts are promoted with either an alkali metal or rare-earth metals to enhance the catalysts’ basicity and reduced the amount of hydrogen strongly adsorbed on the catalyst surface thereby suppressing the hydrogen inhibition phenomenon. The synthesis method, reaction conditions, nature and loading of promoters have effects on the extent of active metal-promoter-support interactions which in turn determine the extent of NH3 conversion and H2 generation. Conclusions The effect of acidic-basic structural modification of nickel-based catalyst on ammonia decomposition resulting from the addition of different promoters was investigated. The addition of a third metal to nickel oxide significantly affected the reduction profile and its magnitude increased by two-fold compared with the original bimetallic catalyst between 400 and 500 °C. Furthermore, the promoters induced more surface basicity sites at the reaction zone for ammonia decomposition. The addition of alkali metal promoters of Na and K to 15%Ni/Al2O3 resulted in stronger basicity sites, enhanced the acidic–basic sites and improving hydrogen desorption from the catalyst surface thereby exhibiting the highest ammonia conversion. The addition of potassium oxide promoter enhanced the stability for ammonia conversion. However, ammonia decomposition activity was affected by space velocity. The catalytic reactivity over trimetallic catalysts was systematically influenced by their basic-acidic properties. The results showed a clear trend for higher catalyst activity which was attributed to the suppressing of hydrogen inhibition effect by the promoters’ addition with a resulting higher ammonia conversion. coredata.dc:description: The utilization of non-precious nickel-based catalyst in increasing ammonia dissociation for COx-free hydrogen production was investigated. Typically, Co, La and basic metal oxides (Na, K, Ba) promoters were synthesized with nickel over acidic gamma alumina support. The main objective of the study was to modify the acid-base surface of catalyst structure thereby increasing ammonia dissociation activity. The catalytic activity for ammonia decomposition was strongly influenced by the addition of Na and K oxide promoters over 15 %Ni/Al2O3 resulting in moderate-stronger basic sites suitable for ammonia conversion. The addition of Na and K oxides showed a clear trend in tuning the trimetallic catalyst and significantly reducing the amount of strongly adsorbed hydrogen on the catalyst surface. This results in higher ammonia conversion which increased as a function of temperature to 32.4 %, 67.5 % and 95.3 % at 430 ᵒC, 485 ᵒC, and 533 ᵒC, respectively. Ammonia conversion using promoters was stable with no degradation of performance and the conversion increased with the decrease in WHSV. The catalytic reactivity over trimetallic catalysts was systematically influenced by their basic-acidic property that promoted ammonia dehydrogenation on the surface of nickel oxide-based catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of acidic–basic structural modification of nickel-based catalyst for ammonia decomposition for hydrogen generation
